question_text: You receive a WhatsApp from your 'daughter' from an unknown number: 'Mom, phone broke, this is my temp number. Can you wire me 500â‚¬ for a new one?'. What is the FIRST thing you do?
options: Call your daughter's OLD number to verify
Ask for a photo of the new phone
explanation_feedback: This is a classic AI social engineering scam. Scammers often spoof profiles. ALWAYS verify voice-to-voice on the original trusted channel before sending money.

question_text: You get an email from 'PayPal Service': 'Unauthorized transaction of $200 detected. Click here to cancel'. The sender is 'service@paypal-support-team.com'.
options: Log in to PayPal directly via your browser
explanation_feedback: Phishing emails create urgency to make you click fake links. 'paypal-support-team.com' is a fake domain. Always go directly to the official app or website.

question_text: Your bank calls you: 'Fraud alert. We need to verify your identity. Please read back the 6-digit code we just texted you.'
options: Hang up and call the number on the back of your card
explanation_feedback: Banks NEVER ask for 2FA codes over the phone. The caller is a scammer trying to log into your account. Hang up and call the official number.

question_text: You're selling a couch online. A buyer sends a check for $500 more than the price and asks you to 'wire back the difference'.
options: Wait for the check to fully clear (can take weeks)
explanation_feedback: This is a 'Overpayment Scam'. The check is fake, but it will initially look valid in your account. When it bounces weeks later, you'll owe the bank the money you wired.

question_text: Which payment method offers the LEAST protection against fraud for online marketplace purchases?
explanation_feedback: Zelle, CashApp, and Wire Transfers are like cash. Once sent, the money is gone. Only use them for friends and family, never for strangers.

question_text: You get a voicemail: 'This is the IRS. A lawsuit is being filed against you. Call back immediately or you will be arrested.'
explanation_feedback: The IRS/Tax Office does NOT initiate contact via phone threats or demand immediate payment. This is a scare tactic. Ignore it.

question_text: An email claims you have a 'Pending Tax Refund' of $450. You just need to click a link and enter your SSN to claim it.
options: Check the official government tax portal
explanation_feedback: Government agencies don't email links for refunds asking for SSNs. Giving your SSN leads to identity theft.

question_text: A 'Government Agent' calls saying your Social Security number was found in a crime scene. They need you to move your money to a 'Safe Account'.
explanation_feedback: There is no such thing as a 'Safe Account' for this purpose. Government agents will never ask you to transfer money to protect it.

question_text: You receive a text: 'Driver License Suspended. Update your info here: dmv-secure-portal.com/login'.
options: Go to the DMV in person
explanation_feedback: Smishing attacks often target licenses. 'dmv-secure-portal.com' is a fake domain. Official sites end in .gov.

question_text: Why do scammers ask for payment in Gift Cards?
explanation_feedback: Gift cards are the currency of scammers because once you give the code, the money is gone and cannot be recovered by banks.

question_text: You get a call from your CEO's voice: 'I need you to wire $50k to this vendor ASAP for a secret project.' It sounds exactly like him.
explanation_feedback: AI can clone voices perfectly. Always verify unusual financial requests through a different communication channel, even if the voice sounds real.

question_text: How much audio does an AI need to clone a voice?
explanation_feedback: Modern AI needs only 3-5 seconds of audio (often taken from social media videos) to create a convincing clone.

question_text: What is a 'Safe Word' in the context of family security?
options: A secret word family members use to verify identity over the phone
A word to stop an argument
explanation_feedback: Establishing a family 'Safe Word' is the best defense against AI voice scams. If the caller doesn't know the word, it's not them.

question_text: You answer a call from an unknown number. The caller asks 'Can you hear me?'. What should you say?
explanation_feedback: Scammers record you saying 'Yes' to authorize fraudulent charges later. It's best to hang up on suspicious unknown callers.

question_text: A video call from a friend looks glitchy and the audio is slightly out of sync. They ask for money.
explanation_feedback: Live Deepfakes exist but often have glitches (blurring around face edges, syncing issues). Be skeptical of video calls asking for money.

question_text: An online 'friend' you've never met recommends a crypto trading platform where they made huge profits.
options: Invest a small amount to test
explanation_feedback: This is 'Pig Butchering'. They build trust over months, let you 'win' small amounts on a fake app, then steal your life savings when you invest more.

question_text: You see an ad with Elon Musk promoting a new 'Quantum AI' trading bot that guarantees 50% returns.
explanation_feedback: Deepfake videos of celebrities are used to promote scams. No investment guarantees high returns with zero risk. If it sounds too good to be true, it is.

question_text: Someone on Telegram offers to 'double your Bitcoin' if you send it to their wallet for 'verification'.
explanation_feedback: Giveaway scams are common. You will never get your crypto back. Legitimate entities never ask you to send funds to verify a wallet.

question_text: What is a 'Rug Pull'?
options: Developers abandoning a crypto project and taking all the money
explanation_feedback: In a Rug Pull, scammers hype a new coin, wait for people to invest, then drain the liquidity pool and disappear.

question_text: A 'Financial Advisor' contacts you on Instagram. Their profile has photos of luxury cars and cash.
explanation_feedback: Real financial advisors don't solicit clients via Instagram DMs with photos of cash. These are lifestyle scams designed to lure victims.

question_text: You find a website selling brand new iPhones for $200. The site is 'apple-discount-store.net'.
explanation_feedback: If a price is impossibly low, it's a scam. Fake stores steal your credit card info. Check the domain age (scam sites are often days old).

question_text: You receive a package you didn't order. A few days later, someone comes to collect it saying it was a mistake.
explanation_feedback: This is a 'Brushing' or 'Address Fraud' scam. Giving the package to a stranger might make you an accomplice to receiving stolen goods. Return it via the official carrier.

question_text: A Facebook Marketplace seller asks you to pay via 'Friends and Family' on PayPal to save fees.
explanation_feedback: 'Friends and Family' payments have NO buyer protection. If they don't ship the item, you cannot get your money back.

question_text: You get an email receipt for a $1000 TV you didn't buy. There is a number to call if you want to 'dispute' it.
options: Check your actual bank statement first
explanation_feedback: This is a 'Refund Scam'. The receipt is fake. If you call, they will try to trick you into giving them remote access to your computer 'to process the refund'.

question_text: A website has a 'Norton Secured' seal, but it's just a static image, not clickable.
explanation_feedback: Real security seals are clickable and verify the site's certificate. Scammers just copy-paste the image to look legit.

question_text: What is 'Credit Freezing'?
options: Locking your credit report so no one can open accounts in your name
explanation_feedback: Freezing your credit at the 3 major bureaus (Equifax, Experian, TransUnion) is the best proactive defense against identity theft.

question_text: You find a USB drive in your office parking lot. What do you do?
options: Plug it in to find the owner
Throw it away / Give to IT security
explanation_feedback: Never plug in found USBs. They can contain malware that installs instantly. Give it to IT or destroy it.

question_text: A job application asks for your SSN and Bank Info before the interview.
explanation_feedback: Legitimate employers only need this info AFTER offering you the job. Asking beforehand is a huge red flag for identity theft.

question_text: You receive a letter about unemployment benefits you didn't apply for.
options: Report it to the state agency immediately
explanation_feedback: This means someone has used your identity to file for benefits. You must report it immediately to avoid tax liability and legal issues.

question_text: How often should you check your bank statements?
explanation_feedback: Regular monitoring helps you spot small 'test charges' from scammers before they drain your account.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You get a call from 'Your Bank's Fraud Dept'. They know your name, address, and last 4 digits of your card. They ask for your PIN to 'freeze' the card.
options: Ask to speak to a manager
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Scammers can buy your personal data (Name, Address, Card info) on the dark web. Knowing this info doesn't prove they are the bank. NEVER give your PIN.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You are investing in a new DeFi project. The developers are anonymous, but the website looks very professional.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Anonymous teams in crypto are a massive risk factor for Rug Pulls. Professional websites are cheap to make. Due diligence requires knowing WHO you are trusting.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: Your boss emails you from a personal Gmail account: 'Urgent, I'm in a meeting. Buy $500 Apple Gift Cards for clients. I will reimburse you.'
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! CEO Fraud (Business Email Compromise) often uses personal emails or spoofing. No legitimate boss asks for Gift Cards for clients via urgent email.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You download a popular crypto wallet app from the App Store. It asks for your 'Seed Phrase' to set up.
options: Check if it's a fake app
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Fake apps often slip into App Stores. If you enter your seed phrase into a fake app, your wallet is drained instantly. Verify the developer and reviews carefully.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: A pop-up on your computer says 'VIRUS DETECTED! Call Microsoft Support immediately'.
options: Force close the browser / Restart computer
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! This is 'Tech Support Fraud'. Microsoft/Apple do not send pop-ups with phone numbers. It's just a browser window stuck in full screen. Restarting usually fixes it.
